question: And that's cricket, hon. You want it? Doesn't matter if you don't. Jody won't be offended. Jody's never offended. What'd you say your name was? Jude. Suits you, Jude.
No, fuck the bear. The name. Jude. And it's June. Jude in June. Gotta piss, Jude. Don't run off, Jude.
answer: You don't know me, do you?

question: What if I did?
answer: You'd know I wouldn't run off.

question: Never pissed holding a girl's hand, Jude.
I never know nothing.
answer: People. They could be looking. Come and get me, soldier --

question: Yeah.
answer: The situation is simple. You're being held hostage by the Irish Republican Army. They've got one of our senior members under interrogation in Castleraigh. We've informed them that if they don't release him within three days, you'll be shot. You'll be treated as our guest until further developments. Have you anything to say?

question: Give him a cup of tea.
answer: Do you want a cup of tea?

question: Did you give him it?
answer: There are certain things I wouldn't do for my country.

question: Poke him or something. See if he's still alive.
You don't know that.
answer: Fucking do. I had him all over me.

question: Tough work, that.
answer: Someone's got to do it. Nah, it was a breeze. Just thought of you. And you know what, Fergus? One of you made me want it...

question: What do you mean you can't?
answer: Can't eat through a canvas bag. This is a farce, man.

question: So, what do I look like?
answer: You're the one about five ten with the killer smile and the baby face.

question: Am I?
answer: Yeah. And the brown eyes. You're the handsome one. Thank you, handsome.

question: I can smell her perfume.
answer: See, if we took the hood off, we'd have to shoot you. As it is, you've got a fifty-fifty chance.

question: Thought you liked me, bitch.
answer: It was fun while it lasted.

question: Made the front page. They'll move now, the fuckers.
answer: Request permission to take the hood off, Tommy.

question: Why would you do that?
answer: The poor whore's suffocating in the heat.

question: So?
answer: And anyway, he's seen our faces.

question: You sure?
answer: He described me down to a T. Knows what Jude looks like. Tommy --

question: You're his keeper. If you don't mind him seeing you, I don't mind. But you're the only one he looks at.
Thank you, soldier. Never thought fresh air would taste this good. Now, if you took the ropes off, I'd be able to feed myself.
Only joking. You know, I was wrong about one thing.
Five ten. Brown eyes. But you're no pinup.
Nope. Not handsome at all.
answer: You trying to hurt my feelings?

question: No. It's the truth.
answer: Well, I could say the same about you.

question: Could you?
answer: But I won't. We're more polite around these parts.

question: You're going to have to do it, aren't you?
They're going to let that guy die. And you're going to kill me.
And even if he doesn't die -- you can't just let me loose.
Not in your nature.
answer: What do you know about my nature?

question: I'm talking about your people, not you.
answer: What the fuck do you know about my people?

question: Only that you're all tough undeluded motherfuckers. And that it's not in your nature to let me go.
answer: Shut the fuck up, would you?

question: And you know the funny thing?
I didn't even fancy her.
answer: Didn't look like that to me...

question: Ah, c'mere. I want to show you something.
My inside pocket. Take out the wallet. Open it. Inside. There's a picture. No, not that one. There's another. Now she's my type.
Don't you think of it, fucker.
She's mine. Anyway, she wouldn't suit you.
Don't I know it.
answer: So what were you fucking around for, then?

question: You fuckers set me up. That bitch --

Okay. That nice lady. Meets me in a bar. I'm saying what the fuck am I doing here anyway. She buys me a drink. She holds my hand. I'm looking at her saying I don't like you, bitch. But what the fuck. Maybe I'll get to understand.
What the fuck am I doing here.
answer: What the fuck were you doing here?

question: It was a job. So I get sent to the only place in the world they call you nigger to your face.
"Go back to your banana tree, nigger." No use telling them I came from Tottenham.
That game where a bunch of paddies whack sticks at each other?

Well, in Antigua cricket's the black man's game. The kids play it from the age of two. My daddy had me throwing googlies from the age of five. Then we moved to Tottenham and it was something different.
Toffs' game there. But not at home. . So when you come to shoot me, Paddy, remember, you're getting rid of a shit- hot bowler.
answer: I'll bear that in mind. And by the way, it's not Paddy. It's Fergus.

question: Nice to meet you, Fergus.
answer: My pleasure, Jody Take it easy, now. Just go slow. Down by that tree.

question: Tree. You've got to loosen my hands.

Well then, you're going to have to take my dick out for me, aren t you? Come on, man, I'm going to wet my pants! Take the fucker out, man, I'm dying -- I gotta lean forward or I'll dribble all over myself. Will you hold my hands for me. Now, that was worth waiting for.
These things take time, Fergus. It's amazing how these small details take on such importance... Now put it back in.
I can't do it! It's only a piece of meat. For fuck's sake, it's got no major diseases. Thank you. I had a case of the clap two years ago. Crabs in Ulster. But all in all it's served me well.
I'm sorry. Didn't mean to offend you, Fergus. Fergus?
Thanks. I know that wasn't easy for you.
You'll have minimal contact with the prisoner, do you hear me?

They giving you trouble, Fergus? It happens. Y'see, there's two kinds of people. Those who give and those who take. Ah, take the thing off, man. It's okay. I understand. Don't mind if I prattle on, do you? I will take it by your silence that you don't. Two types, Fergus. The scorpion and the frog. Ever heard of them? Scorpion wants to cross a river, but he can't swim. Goes to the frog, who can, and asks for a ride. Frog says, "If I give you a ride on my back, you'll go and sting me." Scorpion replies, "It would not be in my interest to sting you since as I'll be on your back we both would drown." Frog thinks about this logic for a while and accepts the deal. Takes the scorpion on his back. Braves the waters. Halfway over feels a burning spear in his side and realizes the scorpion has stung him after all. And as they both sink beneath the waves the frog cries out, "Why did you sting me, Mr. Scorpion, for now we both will drown?" Scorpion replies, "I can't help it, it's in my nature."
answer: So what's that supposed to mean?

question: Means what it says. The scorpion does what is in his nature. Take off the hood, man.
'Cause you're kind. It's in your nature. See? I was right about you.
Jody's always right. Where would you most like to be now, man?
Come on, man. If this shit was all over.
answer: Having a pint in the Rock.

question: You lack imagination, Fergus. Think of something more alluring.
Like having a pint in the Metro --
answer: Having two pints in the Rock.

question: Having a pint in the Metro, and Dil's having a margarita.
We got simple tastes, you and me.
But you fellas never get a break, do you?
Oh, yes. We do a tour of duty and we're finished. But you guys are never finished, are you?
answer: We don't look on it like that.

question: I've often wondered how you do it.
answer: Depends on what you believe in.

question: What do you believe in?
answer: That you guys shouldn't be here.

question: Doesn't matter if he's hot. Just cover the fucker up.
You shut your face -- You're heading for trouble, Fergus --
I said shut the fuck up --
No. Not bad. Women are trouble, you know that, Fergus?
Dil wasn't trouble. No trouble at all.
Present tense, please. Love her. Whatever she is. I'm thinking of her now, Fergus. Will you think of her too?
Want you to do something, Fergus.
But they will. As sure as night follows day. They have to. I want you to find her out. Tell her I was thinking of her. See if she's all right.
Take her picture. C'mere. Take it. In the inside pocket. Take the whole lot. I won't need it.
answer: I told you not to talk that way --

question: Go to Millie's Hair Salon in Spitalfields. Take her to the Metro for a margarita. Don't have to tell her who you are. Just tell her Jody was thinking --
Shut the fuck up, Jude. Why do you want to do that for?
answer: Would make me feel better about it.

question: Okay. You're a good man, Fergus.
How can I?
answer: I don't know. Just help me. Give me a cigarette. Don't even smoke, you know that? It just seemed the right thing to do.

question: Go to sleep now.
answer: I don't want to sleep. Tell me something.

question: Like the one about the frog?
answer: And the scorpion. No. Tell me anything.

question: I thought as a child. But when I became a man I put away childish things...
Nothing.
answer: Tell me something, anything. Not a lot of use, are you, Fergus?

question: No.
answer: I want to see a bit. Please, please. Don't make me die like an animal. I'm glad you're doing it, do you know that, Fergus?

question: Why?
answer: Cause you're my friend. And I want you to go to the Metro --

question: Stop that talk now --
answer: Hurling's a fast game, isn't it, Fergus?

question: Cricket's in the halfpenny place.
answer: So if I ran now, there's no way I'd beat you, is there?

question: You won't run.
answer: But if I did... you wouldn't shoot a brother in the back --

question: I said you bastard -- stop --
answer: Got to catch me first -- Used to run the mile, you know -- four times round the cricket pitch -- what was that game called?

question: Hurling --
answer: Come on, Fergie -- you can do it -- a bit more wind -- Bit of fun, Fergus, eh? Told you I was fast -- Don't do it.

question: Fergus!
answer: You're back in the pink, Tommy? How're you keeping?

question: You'll notice I've asked you nothing.
All right, then. I like to be wise. So what do you need, Fergus?
answer: Need to go across the water.

question: You want something in particular?
answer: Just a bit of a trim...

question: What's his name?
answer: Doesn't the water get to your nails?

question: Like treacle. Nice laugh. That should make her happy.
Don't know. Who is she? Hiya, hon.
Just cut his hair, you know.
Ask him to ask me what I'm drinking.
answer: She wants to know do you want to know what she's drinking.

question: A margarita. Now he can look.... Ask him does he like his hair, Col.
answer: She wants to know, sir, do you like your hair.

question: So can we consider you a regular, sir?
Well, you get to say, The usual, Col. Things like that. So let's call this the usual.
No, no. It's on me. Take it out, if you want. You came to see her, didn't you? Something I should tell you. She's --
Ask him yourself.
answer: So tell me. Everybody wants something.

question: So tell me. Everybody wants something.
Not you. How quaint. How old-fashioned and quaint. Isn't it, Col? You old-fashioned?
He's what she should run a mile from.
Maybe. See, they get the wrong idea.
He wants me to perform for him.
You can't leave me then, can you? You want me to ask you in, right?
If you kissed me, it would really get his goat. Now, if you asked me to meet you tomorrow, it would really drive him insane.
Half-five. At Millie's. Give me that look again.
The one you gave me in the Metro. Darling, you shouldn't have.
I wonder. Now's the time you're meant to do something, isn't it?
Make a pass or something. Isn't that the way it goes?
You got a special friend, Jimmy?
The things a girl has to put up with. I'm frightened, Jimmy. That's not like him. Piss off, Dave!
answer: Tough guy, huh? Are you going to be all right on your own?

question: I'm not on my own, am I? Come on up, would you? Won't hurt you to come in. Would you like a drink?
Jesus fucking Christ. Hey, Stirling fucking Moss --
answer: It's Dave. Talk to me, Dil --

question: Take your clothes.
answer: Don't throw my clothes out the window!

question: Fuck off back to Essex!
answer: Fucking mad! Don't chuck my clothes out!

question: Sorry. How'd he drive with his neck in a brace?
answer: Must be in love to manage that.

question: Doesn't know the meaning of the word.
Tried to. Sit down, will you?
As different as it's possible to be.
Yes. No --
answer: Did you do that to him?

question: You want to know how I kissed him?
Can't think. He's dead. In Ireland. He was a soldier. Went there like a fool.
You say that like a gentleman.
Like you're concerned. But you can t stay, you know that?
Fuck off, Dave.
answer: No, I won't fucking fuck off. Said I'm sorry, didn't I?

question: Yeah. I heard. You hear, Jimmy?
answer: I was only going to ask her for a dance. Shall we? Did he come here too?

question: Is this an obsession of yours?
So what do you want with me, Jimmy?
What does that mean?
answer: Something I heard someone say once.

question: Why?
answer: If I told you, you wouldn't believe me.

question: You're not having me on, are you? 'Cause Dil can't stand that.
And she does get very upset... One for him, too. Drink.
I'm superstitious. Drink. Can't leave me now.
The thing is, can you go the distance?
No, depends on nothing. In one. What you thinking of, hon?
Why?
answer: I'm wondering why you keep his things.

question: Told you, I'm superstitious.
answer: Did he ever tell you you were beautiful?

question: He looks after me. He's a gentleman too. Give me one minute.
You did know, didn't you? Oh my God.

Don't go, Jimmy -- I'm sorry. I thought you knew. What were you doing in the bar if you didn't know -- I'm bleeding... It's all right, Jimmy. I can take it. Just not on the face. Y'see, I'm not a young thing any longer.... Funny the way things go. Don't you find that, Jimmy? Never the way you expected.
You mean that? Don't go like that. Say something... Jesus. He's back, Col
Don't want any of those looks, Col. They don't mean much.
No. Tell him to go fuck himself.
answer: She wants me to tell you go fuck yourself.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Tell him to stop messing Dil around --

question: How much did that frame cost, Mr. Franknum? Your Pat just cost me two hundred quid.
Sorry won't bring the bloody thing back, will it, Mr. Franknum? Off his wages.
He wants to know do I mean that. Bloody right I do... Is that his tart? Does Pat have a tart?
No, of course not, she's a lady.
She's not that either.
answer: Darling -- Never let the sun go down on an argument, Jody used to say.

question: What you doing here?
answer: Got your note. So let's kiss and make up, hon.

question: Give it over, Dil --
answer: Apologies, my sweet. That's more like it, dear. Have a cuppa.

question: You're something else, Dil, you know that?
answer: Never said a truer word. See, I was always best looking after someone. Must be something in the genes.

question: Must be.
answer: And the fact that you didn't know is basically the fault of yours truly. And even when you were throwing up, I could tell you cared.

question: Yeah. I care, Dil. You crying, Dil?
Do it on your own time, Paddy.
Whatever it is she does for you.
answer: If I was her I'd consider that an insult.

question: Consider it how you like. Just get that bloody tart out of here.
answer: Did you ever pick your teeth up with broken fingers?

question: What's that supposed to mean?
answer: It's a simple question. Come on, dear.

question: It's a simple question. Come on, dear.
answer: He didn't answer, honey -- My, oh my, Jimmy, how gallant.

question: Shut up.
answer: Made me feel all funny inside.

question: I said stop it.
answer: Ask me to meet you again, Jimmy.

question: I didn't mean to hit you.
Kind of liked you as a girl.
So I'm sorry.
answer: Make it up to me, then.

question: Know what I didn't know. And don't call me that.
answer: Can't help it, Jimmy. A girl has her feelings.

question: Thing is, Dil, you're not a girl.
I should have known, shouldn't I?
That's true.... Your soldier knew, didn't he?
Won't be quite the same though, will it?
I'm working on it. There's Dave. He knew too.
Okay. Be a good girl and go inside.
Hello, stranger. You vanished. What was it, Fergus? Did you blow the gaff on us or did you just fuck up?
No. That's the last thing I'll do. You never asked what happened.
Maguire and me got out by the skin of our teeth. No thanks to you.... What you think of the hair?

Aye, I was sick of being blond. Needed a tougher look, if you know what I mean. Fuck me, Fergus. Am I to take it that's a no? We had a court-martial in your absence. They wanted to put a bullet in your head. I pleaded for clemency. Said we should find out what happened first. So what did happen?
answer: He ran. I couldn't shoot him in the back. I tried to catch him. He made it to the road and got hit by a Saracen.

question: But you know what the thing is, Fergus?
You vanished quite effectively. Became Mister Nobody. And you've no idea how useful that could be.
We've got some plans here. And we'll need a Mister Nobody to execute them.
You're never out, Fergus. Maybe you don't care whether you die or not. But consider the girl, Fergus. The wee black chick.
Jesus, Fergus, you're a walking cliche. You know we won't leave her out of this. But I'm glad to see you care. And I must admit I'm curious.
answer: What the fuck do you know, Jude?

question: He'd bring me carnations.
answer: So I got it wrong, then.

question: What's wrong, Jimmy? Tell me what's wrong
You following me?
answer: Yeah. Just checking. He being nice to you, Dil?

question: Ever so nice. Aren't you, Jimmy?
answer: That's good. I'm glad. Young love, as they say.

question: Absolutely. The younger the better. Doesn't come your way much, I suppose.
answer: Don't go looking for it, Dil.

question: Well, maybe you'll get lucky. Someday.
answer: A bit heavy on the powder, isn't she, Jimmy?

question: A girl has to have a bit of glamour.
answer: Absolutely. Long as she can keep it. Isn't that right, James...

question: She's the thing you had to tell me.
I'm sorry, you know that? I'm really sorry. You see that, Col?
Fuck it, is what I say.
And fuck you, Jimmy --
answer: You could always make it up to her.

question: You could always make it up to her.
When a girl runs out like that, she generally wants to be followed.
So it was you all the time.
I thought it was Dave.
answer: And who's Dave when he's at home?

question: He's at home.
answer: Should blow you away, you know that?

question: I know that.
answer: I'm getting emotional. And I don't want to get fucking emotional -- you understand, Hennessy?

question: That true, Fergus? You in love?
And what's she like between the sheets?
And you know what'll happen if you fuck up again, don't you?
Good. So what do you think that is, Hennessy?
It's a knocking-shop. Tres discreet, huh? He visits his ladies on Tuesday and Thursday nights and Saturday mornings. His security's in the car beyond.
Doesn't matter who he is. He is what we would call a legitimate target.
Good. So what do you think?
answer: Whoever hits him'll be hit, if those men are any good. And I presume you can't get in.

question: Right.
answer: Kind of suicide, isn't it? But, then, I don't have a choice.

question: Kind of suicide, isn't it? But, then, I don't have a choice.
Of course. I forgot.
answer: Come on, Fergie. A rehearsal. You keep your mind on the job, boy --

question: And then you'll leave her out of it?
answer: Aye. Then we'll leave her be. He's arthritic. Takes him two minutes to get to the door.

question: And what if I say no?
answer: You know what. Go. You were made for this.

question: And what happens then?
answer: We'll be on the other side. We'll move when you do.

question: And what if you don't?
answer: Fergus, I think you don't trust me.

question: You may be right.
answer: Stay late at your work tomorrow night and I'll bring you the gear.

question: Shouldn't be, Dil
answer: Why shouldn't I be jealous? Don't. My makeup. She own you, Jimmy?

question: You could say that.
answer: And you're not going to tell me more?

question: I'm not sure.
answer: Do you like me even a little bit?

question: More than that. Come on, let's go for a walk. You do something for me, Dil?
You got the keys to the shop?
No. Sit down. You'd do anything for me?
You said anything, Dil
answer: A girl has to draw the line somewhere --

question: Want to change you to a man, Dil...
It's a secret.
answer: You'd like me better that way, Jimmy?

question: I promise.
answer: Go on, then. You're no good at this, Jimmy.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: You want to make me look like him...

question: No. Want to make you into something new. That nobody recognizes...
What?
answer: You like me better like this.

question: No. No. Dil... get up...
answer: Baby... What are you doing, honey...

question: For me.
answer: For you... Why are we going here, Jimmy?

question: Look on it like a honeymoon.
I take pride in my work.
answer: I sincerely hope so. Tools of the trade. And forget about the girl.

question: Dil? Dil! Dil! What the fuck are you doing here?
Told you to stay in the hotel!
answer: Thought you was fooling me. Thought you was leaving me.

question: I had to go to work!
answer: Stayed all day in that room thinking every noise was you. There's something you're not telling me, Jimmy.

question: Come on...
answer: No! I'm going home... So tell me.

question: I was trying to get out of something.
You got to forget you ever saw me, Dil.
Yes. Stop it, would you? Give it over, Dil, for fuck's sake --
answer: Sorry. I get nervous. I got this blood condition. Just help me inside, Jimmy, then I'll be all right.

question: You heard what I said, Dil?
Are you supposed to take that many?
answer: Only in times of extreme stress. See, they all say good-bye sometime. 'Cept for him.

question: Are you all right, Dil?
answer: I will be. Go on, then.

question: What?
answer: Don't go like that. Can't help what I am. Knew you had a heart...

question: Dil Can I tell you something? I knew your man.
Lifted him from a carnival in Belfast. Held him hostage for three days.
I got the order to shoot him. Before I could do it he ran. Ran into a tank and died.
You should scream. You should beat my head off.
Don't you want to kill me?
answer: Bang... Don't leave me tonight. Might kill me, too.

question: Okay. What the fuck --
answer: So tell me what you're doing, Jimmy. Didn't really listen last night. I heard but I didn't listen. That won't do you no good. Dil knows how to tie a body. Wondered why you came on to me like that when you gave me the look.

question: He asked me to see were you all right.
answer: See, I fix on anyone that's nice to me. Just the littlest bit nice and I'm yours.

question: Stop it, Dil --
answer: Just don't kick Dil and she'll be touched. Be nice to her and she'll be yours forever. See, I should blow you away, Jimmy. But I can't do that. Yet.

question: Give me a bit more, baby, a bit more.
What would you do for me?
Say it again.
answer: I'd do anything for you, Dil.

question: I know you're lying, Jimmy, but it's nice to hear it.
What was that she called you, Jimmy?
